chapter.title: Learn to Use OmegaT in 15 Minutes!

section.title: OmegaT principles
section.para: OmegaT is a computer-assisted translation (CAT) tool that offers great flexibility and performance, as well as features beyond those of commercial offerings, even for beginning translators.

listitem.para: An OmegaT translation project consists of a folder that stores a number of resources in separate subfolders. Translators can easily modify the contents of the subfolders at any time during the translation simply by copying, moving or deleting files.

At a minimum, resources include at the minimum the project's translation memory, which is automatically upon project creation, and the files to translate. It can also include reference translation memories, glossaries, and other reference files.
Translators do not have to create a translation memory or associate one to a new project. OmegaT takes care of that automatically.

Translators can very easily reuse an existing project's translation memory by simply adding new translation files to the old project, or by copying the old translation memory to the new project's folder.

There is no limit to the number of translation memories that can be used as reference in a translation project, and OmegaT makes it very easy to assign different levels of priority to these additional memories.
Translators can easily collaborate on a project.
The team functionality synchronizes the project's translation memory and main glossary between all participants, and allows easy resolution of conflicts between different translations.

section.title: Set up a new project
section.para: To start using OmegaT, first create a project to hold all your files, such as your source files, translation memories, glossaries, and eventually your translated files.
In the menu, use and enter a name for your project. Remember where you are creating the project, because you will need to return to it later.
The Create New Project dialog opens after you have named your project. At the top of that dialog, select the languages of your source and translated files, and click the OK button to continue.
If you are interested in other settings of this dialog, you can return to it any time by using to display the dialog.

Next, the dialog opens. Click on to select your source files. OmegaT will then copy the selected files to the folder of your newly created project. After the source files have loaded in the pane, you can close the dialog.

section.title: Translate your files
section.para: In the pane, OmegaT will present one segment at a time for you to translate. After you have typed the translation of a segment, use to move to the next untranslated segment. Once you leave the segment, its translation is automatically stored into the project translation memory located in the folder of the project and will be used as reference for the rest of your translation. You can manually register glossary items that you want to later use in the translation with .
See the menu for more navigation options.

When you enter a segment that matches some of the content of the project translation memories, OmegaT displays the matches in the pane. Similarly, if there are terms matching the contents of the glossaries, the terms and their translations are displayed in the pane.
Use the menu to manage translation memory matches and perform other various useful functions. Use in the menu and in the to manage glossary matches.

With , you can search the whole project for terms, sentence fragments and so on, using exact, keyword, or regular expression searches, as well as narrow the scope of the based on information such as author or date. You can also focus only on the results by filtering them in the Editor. See
for details. You can replace terms with by using a similar dialog. See for details.
You can leave notes to yourself or team members in the pane while you translate, and go back to annotated segments with or in the menu, or from the window.
The various panes give easy access to some frequently used function through a context menu. See for details. The auto-completion menu is also available in the Editor pane. See for details.

section.title: Manage your tags
section.para: If the documents you translate use bold, italics, or other decorative elements, OmegaT will convert them into tags that enclose the decorated text. Such files include LibreOffice files, HTML files, Microsoft Office files, etc. Documents will often also contain tags that have nothing to do with decorations, but are nevertheless important in the source files (and, consequently, in the translated files as well). A source sentence might look like:

example.title: Sentence with decorative formatting
example.para: OmegaT is an easy to use program for eager translators

section.para: Depending on the original format, OmegaT, however, will present this sentence in a fashion similar to this one:

example.title: How decorations are displayed in OmegaT
example.para: OmegaT is an <t0/>easy to use<t1/> program for <t2/>eager<t3/> translators

section.para: The tags in OmegaT are greyed, making them easy to recognize. They are protected to prevent you from modifying their contents, but you can delete them, enter them by hand or move them around in the target sentence. See and for details.
You can define custom tags that will be managed in the same manner. See for details. You can also define strings that OmegaT should warn you about if you leave them in a translation. See for details.

If you make mistakes when you type the formatting tags, your translated files might fail to open. Use
to validate that your tags are correct before you generate your translated files.

warning.para: If a file refuses to open in LibreOffice, Word or other application, it is often due to errors in the management of OmegaT tags. Return to OmegaT, validate the tags and recreate the translated file.

section.title: Generate the translated files
section.para: Whenever you want to see what your translation will look like in its final format, use to generate the translated documents, which will be created in the folder of your project.

note.para: You translations are always stored in the project translation memory, located in the folder of your project. Deleting the contents of the folder will never impact your translations.

section.para: Once the translated files have been created, you can open them in their original application to check their contents and eventually further modify them. Such modifications will not be reflected in OmegaT.

It is common practice to review a translation in OmegaT, with the , the function (that includes grammatical checks), as well as by making changes to the layout and options, and to then create the translated files to further review them in their original application.

Modifications made outside OmegaT can be reinserted in OmegaT (and thus in the project translation memory, to keep it up to date) either by entering them manually in the relevant segments, or by aligning the original file and the final translated file to create a new translation memory (TMX) file that will be put in the subfolder of your project folder. See for details.

warning.para: Any time you create the translated files, any previously created files with the same name will be overwritten. If you want to keep files from being overwritten, change their name after you created them, or automate the name modification with of the preferences.

section.title: A few more things to note

listitem.para: If a file does not appear into the pane, then it could be that it is in a format that doesn't work in OmegaT. See in the for a list of file formats that OmegaT can handle.
Translation projects are just folders containing files. You can create a new project for each new job, or you can add new source files to an existing project at anytime.
You can access and modify the project settings with . To see the list of files in the project, use .
Every time you create the translated files (see , above), OmegaT creates three translation memories that contain the state of the translation of the files currently in the folder.

The three files are located inside the folder and are called (project name)-level1.tmx, (project name)-level2.tmx and (project name)-omegat.tmx. They can be used as reference translation memories in other projects.
The level1 and level2 suffixes refer to the TMX standard (see TMX 1.4b Specification). You can share these files with users of other translation programs.
You can use the file with the omegat suffix in other (current or future) OmegaT translation projects as a reference translation memory simply by copying it to the folder or a new project.
For a more comprehensive introduction see OmegaT for beginners on the OmegaT web site. If you need assistance with any aspect of OmegaT, feel free to join the OmegaT user group.
